records.briefDefinition: High, powerful shoulder-or overhead guard that can launch all blows and oppose them, used to seize initiative and break guards with committed strikes.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Stand with the sword chambered on the shoulder (right or left) or lifted high (soprana), hands near the head, point rearward or slightly upward. Body is coiled for a descending fendente or a swift feint-to-thrust. From Donna you can beat aside attacks or enter the bind with advantage; guards similar to it are its counters, but Donna claims the high line and striking momentum.  ￼
records.application: Open with mandritto/riverso fendenti; threaten thrusts out of the feint; break static guards by driving through the center.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Use Donna in zufechta to force reactions. If the opponent thrusts high, cross and exchange/break the thrust; if they cut, beat or overbind and finish with fendente or punta. Rotate between Donna and Fenestra to vary lines while maintaining upper-line pressure. In Vadi, related high guards retain quick advance-strike-recover timing.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Overhead variant of Donna that deceives with a raised cut and quickly converts to a thrust.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Lift the hilt above the head, point back; show a descending blow, then turn the hands and shoot the point straight down the center. The extra height lengthens the thrust path and increases leverage for strong parries against descending blows.  ￼
records.application: Feint cut → snap thrust; or drop the hands into fendente against committed entries.  ￼
records.fullApplication: From Soprana, threaten head/shoulder; if opponent rises to parry, turn the hands and deliver a direct punta; if they remain low, crash with fendente to bind and work stretto plays. Use as a momentary deception rather than a resting guard.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Left-side Donna that covers and strikes from the off side, beating thrusts down and launching powerful riversi.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Chamber the sword on the left shoulder; hips loaded to deliver riverso fendente or to beat down incoming points. It mirrors right-side Donna in power and options but threatens different lines and hand targets.  ￼
records.application: Answer right-handers’ inside thrusts by beating down and counter-cutting; open with riverso fendente into mezza spada.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Use left Donna to invite a forehand and to counter with a strong riverso into bind; feel (sentire) for opposition and wind to thrust if resisted. Transition on the step to Fenestra Sinestra to threaten a quick punta.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: High-line guard at head level ("window"), quick for deceit and thrusting, with strong defensive crossings.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Hold the hilt beside the temple, point forward across the line. From here, strike with short thrusts, exchange/break incoming thrusts, or deliver mezzani. The compact hand position enables fast parry-riposte.  ￼
records.application: Threaten direct punta; if opposed, beat or exchange and riposte; use to bait and counter high blows.  ￼
records.fullApplication: In zufechta, carry Fenestra to set a central threat; when the opponent commits a thrust, shift the point offline and thrust through (scambiar di punta); against cuts, cross high and answer with a short thrust or redoubled mezzano.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Window guard on the left side; mirrors right Fenestra, enabling swift off-side thrusts and parry-ripostes.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Hilt beside left temple, point forward; favors quick riverso-line thrusts and cross-parries against mandritti. Transitions fluidly to Longa or Donna on the step.  ￼
records.application: Use against right-side pressure to threaten inside-line thrusts; exchange or break thrusts and riposte.  ￼
records.fullApplication: From left Fenestra, invite a right-hand cut; meet it with a tight cross and stab into the opening; if bound, wind to Longa and keep the point on.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Vadi's "true window" presented on the left with a lower, more forward window-line presentation.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Carry the window with lead-side advance and the point projecting more forward than Fiore’s depiction. Functions as a thrust-centric, deceptive high-line guard within Vadi’s timing model.  ￼
records.application: Probe with short punta; recover on the retreat step; mix with Falcone and Sagittaria to vary entry lines.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Use Vera Fenestra to control center; if crossed, take mezzo tempo to stab during their recovery; otherwise wheel (rota) into horizontal pressure to hands.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Close, withdrawn point-on guard—deceptive for short thrusts; Fiore notes it ‘wants a long sword’ and lacks stability as a base.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Arms drawn in, hilt near chest/face, point centered. It tempts with short lunging thrusts and quick retractions, but the compact structure is not for prolonged waiting.  ￼
records.application: Snipe with short punta; if pressed, slip to Longa or beat to Corona; do not camp here.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Use briefly to provoke parry; when they extend, take mezzo tempo thrust; if they rush, drop to Iron Gate variants to receive and counter.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Extended point-threat with arms long; Fiore calls it ‘full of deception’, ideal for testing defenses and striking with direct thrusts.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Extend hands and point straight to the target, body balanced. From here, disengage to thrust, void cuts, or convert to binds without ceding the center.  ￼
records.application: Use as probing guard to force reactions; exchange thrusts favoring longer reach.  ￼
records.fullApplication: In zufechta, carry Longa to measure; if their point searches, strike in mezzo tempo; if they cut, withdraw the hands and stab as the cut passes; or shift to Corona to catch descending blows.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Centered, point-up crossing guard like a ‘crown’; intercepts and deflects high/low attacks with strong crossings.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Hold the hilt centered, point rising; meet high thrusts by crossing offline, beat low thrusts to ground, and absorb descending cuts into the crown to riposte.  ￼
records.application: Adopt when expecting incoming blows; convert catches to immediate ripostes.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Use Corona as a defensive hub: invite, catch on the crown, then step to flank and answer with fendente or punta to face/hands. Transition to Bicorno if you need a locked, point-on center threat.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Low, centered Iron Gate with the point forward; a stable waiting guard that easily thrusts into attacks.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Hilt near hip/midline, tip aimed at opponent’s center. Receive blows on the strong, then thrust through the opening or rise with fendente to enter stretto.  ￼
records.application: Wait out attacks; stop-thrust, then cover out; or rise with fendente to hands.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Against cut entries, let them fall onto your strong, turn the point into their forward line and thrust; if parried, follow with redoubled mezzano. Vadi lists the position among his longsword guards.  ￼

records.originalTerm: Tutta Porta di Ferro (Porta di Ferro Piana Terrena)
records.briefDefinition: Very low Iron Gate with blade near the ground (‘flat to the earth’); strong for beating aside thrusts and waiting.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Lower the hands and point so the blade nearly rests to the earth, stance rooted. Beat low thrusts outward and rise into counter-attacks as the opponent extends.  ￼
records.application: Adopt when receiving; break thrusts downward and answer with rising cuts or thrusts.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Use to deny low-line stabs and leg blows; as they overreach, step and deliver sottano → fendente sequence to hands/head, or thrust straight from the lift.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Rear-weighted, sword extended low behind like a tail; a waiting guard that transitions quickly to thrust or descending cut.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Typically right foot back, blade low to right rear. Draws attacks, then steps forward with fendente or uncurls into a thrust as you enter narrow play.  ￼
records.application: Bait, then step-cut; or spring a thrust as they advance.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Use Coda Longa to create tempo; when they strike, slip the target and answer with a step-in fendente to bind, then work stretto. If they hesitate, advance to Longa to take center.  ￼

records.originalTerm: Posta di Coda Longa la Sinestra
records.briefDefinition: Left-side mirror of Long Tail, sword low behind the left flank, offering analogous waiting and counter-attacking lines.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Reverse the tail position to the left; favors riverso and false-edge actions on the rise, with easy rotation into Boar’s Tooth on the left.  ￼
records.application: Use to draw forehand blows and reply with riverso or rising thrust.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Against right-handers, let the mandritto overshoot and cut riverso to the arms; if they thrust, break it downward and step to their flank.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Low left-lead guard named for the boar’s tusk; launches rising thrusts and hand-attacks as the opponent enters.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Left foot forward, hilt near hip, point angled upward toward the opponent’s hands; attack ‘as a boar with its lower teeth’, then follow with cuts. Excellent counter-offensive base.  ￼
records.application: Stop-hit the hands with a rising punta; pursue with fendente/mezzano.  ￼
records.fullApplication: When they extend, stab up the middle to the hands/face; if their blade beats yours, let it pass and redouble with mezzano to forearms; recover to Iron Gate if measure closes awkwardly.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Variant of Boar’s Tooth at a more central/mid height noted in some traditions of Fiore’s material. (Scholarly note: naming varies across manuscripts.)  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Carry Dente di Cinghiaro slightly higher and centered to emphasize immediate thrusts to the face while retaining low-line counter options. Use as a transitional presentation rather than a static pose.  ￼
records.application: Threaten direct centerline punta; drop to full Iron Gate if pressed low.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Against cautious opponents, show mid-height tusk to provoke a beat; disengage and stab; if they close, sink to Tutta Porta and reset the threat from below.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Tight, point-on guard with hilt close and point locked on center so it cannot be displaced.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Hands near the face/chest, quillons like ‘two horns’; point threatens straight ahead. Ideal for holding center against entries and for sudden straight thrusts.  ￼
records.application: Fix the opponent in the line; take the first intention thrust when they move.  ￼
records.fullApplication: If they attempt to beat, yield minimally and replace the point (remiso) into their advance; if they cut, raise to Corona or slip and stab from the close.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Vadi-specific high guard, kin to Donna but with different timing/line, favoring quick advance-strike-recover actions.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Adopt a high carriage with readiness to step the lead foot and immediately deliver a descending or diagonal blow, recovering back to guard per Vadi’s cadence.  ￼
records.application: Use as a mobile striking platform to preempt or punish slow entries.  ￼
records.fullApplication: From Falcone, take the Vor with a sharp fendente; if they attempt to parry, turn the hands and stab in mezzo tempo; recover to Vera Fenestra or Sagittaria.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Low, forward-projecting guard akin to a lower, more forward Fenestra; name borrowed from armored context.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Project the point forward at mid-high line with a compressed structure, prepared to dart a thrust like an archer’s shot and recover.  ￼
records.application: Probe with straight punta; if opposed, wheel to rota or retreat to Vera Fenestra.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Use Sagittaria to contest center against long guards; take single-time thrusts as they shift; if they cut, slip under and riposte with volante.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Vadi shows an additional boar’s-tooth-type guard with opposite foot lead from the usual depiction.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Adopt boar’s-tooth mechanics but switch the forward leg; this alters entry angles and hand targets while retaining rising thrust utility.  ￼
records.application: Use to confound expectations about your lead and hand targets while keeping tusk-style counters.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Show the ‘wrong’ lead to invite a habitual parry; cut across it with a quick riverso or a lift-thrust to the hands, then step to close if they overextend.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Downward blows that ‘split the teeth to the knee’, breaking guards and returning to guard along their path.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Deliver diagonally or vertically from high line, true-edge leading, with whole-body rotation and step. Finish in low guards or recover by retracting along the same line.  ￼
records.application: Primary power attack to seize Vor or smash static guards.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Open with fendente to bind; if parried, wind to thrust or redouble with mezzano. Against lower guards, strike down the center to force a weak catch.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Ascending blows that travel the same road as fendente but from knee up, often seeking the hands.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Cut up from low to high with either edge, often from Iron Gate or Boar’s Tooth; immediately follow with a descending reply if needed.  ￼
records.application: Hand-hunting counter to incoming entries; set up redoubling.  ￼
records.fullApplication: When the opponent extends, lift with sottano to hands/arms, then drop a fendente to head or recover to Longa to maintain point-on threat.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Horizontal/diagonal-horizontal blows above the knee that ‘thwart’, beat thrusts, and redouble.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Travel roughly horizontal; used to interrupt lines, beat points aside, and maintain continuous offense between high and low actions.  ￼
records.application: Use as redouble after parries; beat thrusts off-line.  ￼
records.fullApplication: From a bind, take short mezzano to hands, then wheel into another cut (rota) or thrust; if their point threatens, strike the blade aside with a mezzo and enter.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Any blow from the fencer’s right (forehand) side—can be fendente, mezzano, or sottano. (Terminological convention across Italian sources.)
records.detailedDescription: Generate from right shoulder/hip; true-edge for descending/horizontal, false-edge possible on rising; pair with steps to close or angle.
records.application: Default power-side actions; combine with riverso sequences to keep tempo.
records.fullApplication: Open with mandritto fendente to bind; if they slip, follow with mandritto mezzano to hands, then thrust through the center. (General usage across Fiore/Vadi.)

records.briefDefinition: Any blow from the left (backhand) side; rising riversi often use the false edge, descending the true edge.
records.detailedDescription: Deliver from left shoulder/hip; excellent for striking across the opponent’s weapon arm and for redoubling after a forehand.
records.application: Punish overcommitted forehands; follow mandritti for continuous pressure.
records.fullApplication: After parrying inward, snap riverso mezzano to the hands and recover point-on; if they rush, drop to stretto and finish with pommel/throw per plays.

records.briefDefinition: Any cut made with the back (false) edge; common on rising or backhand actions to create fast, short lines.
records.detailedDescription: Rotate the hands so the false edge leads; useful for quick lifts from low guards and for deceptive changes of line in binds.
records.application: Use falso sottano to snipe hands en route to fendente; use falso to disengage and re-enter.
records.fullApplication: When pressed on your true edge, turn the hands to falso to slip their bind and strike the open line, then return to true-edge structure for power.

records.briefDefinition: Point attack along the body’s midline; Fiore enumerates five thrusts; Vadi extols the thrust as venomous and rival to all blows.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Drive the point with shoulders and step; keep the line between groin and forehead; exchange against high thrusts or break opposing thrusts before delivering your own.  ￼
records.application: Probe from Longa/Fenestra; exchange or break in defense; finish binds with short stabs.  ￼
records.fullApplication: From a central guard, feint cut and deliver a straight punta; if met, disengage and thrust other side; if they thrust, take scambiar di punta with an offline step.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Vadi’s circular, turning blow that can flow through forehand fendente and destroy hands as it wheels.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: A horizontal/curving strike delivered with rotational body-mechanics; often chained between other cuts to maintain continuous pressure on the opponent’s weapon arm.  ￼
records.application: Use to redouble after a parry or to cut through recovering lines to hands/forearms.  ￼
records.fullApplication: After beating a thrust aside, wheel the blade in rota across the hands; if they chase, reverse into a second rota or finish with a thrust under cover.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Vadi’s upward diagonal blows ‘from the knee up’ that often banish downward blows and thrusts.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Rise sharply from low line, commonly on the left/false-edge, crossing center to intercept or preempt the opponent’s descending or point attacks.  ￼
records.application: Answer high-line pressure with a fast rising volante; follow with fendente or thrust.  ￼
records.fullApplication: When they begin a high cut, step slightly offline and throw volante to the hands under the blow, then redouble down the opened line before they recover.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Phase where blades meet around the middle; neither has clear advantage and actions tend toward close play.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: At the mid-bind, feel for pressure; wind, thrust, strike the hands, or enter to grapple (zogho stretto). Control their point before closing.  ￼
records.application: Use to transition from wide to close play; execute pommel strikes, disarms, or short thrusts.  ￼
records.fullApplication: From mezza spada, if they are hard, go soft and wind to thrust; if they are soft, press through with fendente or grab the hilt to throw; always secure the line before body entries.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Actions at wider distance: crossings at mid/tip or without crossing, leaving room to strike or withdraw without immediate grappling.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Parry at mid-blade and strike with free hands; maintain measure; avoid body contact unless advantage is created.  ￼
records.application: Use largo to test and wound safely; convert to stretto only when binding close.  ￼
records.fullApplication: If the bind occurs near the tips, strike to openings and exit; if pressure collapses distance, shift to stretto tactics.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Actions at close distance: crossings nearer the hilt/half-sword leading to grappling, pommel strikes, and disarms.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: With short measure and bound blades, control their weapon, then use off-hand, pommel, or throws while protecting the line.  ￼
records.application: Enter when the bind collapses; finish quickly with holds or short thrusts.  ￼
records.fullApplication: From stretto, if their point is free, close it with your hilt and strike with pommel; if you gain the outside, throw or off-balance before they recover.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Counter-thrust against an incoming thrust by stepping offline and driving your point into them as theirs is voided.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: As their thrust comes, take a slight offline step, cross/beat just enough to clear, and thrust straight into their opening; recover or pursue as needed.  ￼
records.application: Use when you read a committed thrust and have line advantage.  ￼
records.fullApplication: From Longa/Fenestra, if they lunge, shift head/torso off line, deflect minimally, and stab to face/chest; continue to bind only if the exchange fails.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Beat/deflect the opponent’s thrust aside with a strike (often a descending blow) to void the line and open a riposte.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Meet the incoming point with a sharp cut onto the blade (typically fendente/mezzano), driving it off-line; immediately answer with a thrust or cut.  ￼
records.application: Preferred when timing or reach denies a safe exchange of thrust.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Against a central lunge, step offline, strike the blade down with fendente, and thrust over it; if they resist, bind to mezza spada and finish per stretto plays.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: An overly strong, crude overhand strike used as a teaching scenario; Fiore shows how to evade/intercept and counter as it overcommits.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: As the heavy high blow descends, void the line or meet it early; then seize the moment of imbalance to thrust, strike, or throw. Emphasizes timing against raw strength.  ￼
records.application: Train counters to committed, telegraphed strikes; develop offline entries.  ￼
records.fullApplication: Step off line as it falls; catch or let it pass; immediately thrust to face or take the arms; if they crash in, transition to stretto grappling.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Strike in the middle of the opponent’s action—‘just one turn of the wrist: quick and immediately striking’.  ￼
records.detailedDescription: Exploit small motion to land before their action completes: a short thrust, a quick hand turn, or a compact cut taken on their preparation or extension.  ￼
records.application: Use against wide preparations or slow recoveries; favors compact guards (Vera Fenestra, Longa).  ￼
records.fullApplication: As they raise to cut, turn the hands and deliver a straight punta before their blow falls; if they disengage, take a short rota to the hands, keeping time advantage.  ￼

records.briefDefinition: Short lead-foot advance that increases stance length and closes measure without a full pass.
records.detailedDescription: Lead foot steps forward a small amount; rear foot may follow to re-establish stance. Used to approach safely, provoke, or set up actions while remaining balanced. Vadi favors striking off a quick lead-foot advance and recovering immediately.
records.application: Probe from Longa/Fenestra; gain a tempo and line without over-commitment; pair with point-on threats and immediate ripostes.
records.fullApplication: In onset, accrescere from Longa to force a parry; if they cut, void or cover and thrust in mezzo tempo; if they hesitate, accrescere again to enter a bind or pass offline with a fendente.

records.briefDefinition: Short lead-foot withdrawal that shortens stance and opens measure without a full pass back.
records.detailedDescription: Lead foot moves back toward the rear foot, reducing reach and buying time. Used to make attacks fall short, let strikes land on the forte, and create space for counters.
records.application: Create evasive space during their attack; make a blow miss or weaken on contact; reset measure to re-enter on your terms.
records.fullApplication: Parry a cut on your strong while discressere to void its power, then accrescere back in with a thrust; or discressere to deny grappling measure and re-establish largo play.

records.briefDefinition: Rear foot passes forward to become lead, covering ground for committed entries and powerful blows.
records.detailedDescription: A deep forward step, ideally taken slightly offline, that couples body mass to the strike or cover. Standard mechanic for entering narrow play and breaking guards with force.
records.application: From Donna or Coda Longa, pass forward with fendente or thrust to seize initiative and close safely.
records.fullApplication: Step the front foot slightly offline, then pass with the rear foot as you cover and strike; arrive on their flank, bind on your forte, and finish with thrust or second cut.

records.briefDefinition: Lead foot passes back to become rear, retreating in one action while keeping guard.
records.detailedDescription: Reverse of the forward pass. Used to exit measure quickly after a failed action or to deny the opponent a safe riposte.
records.application: Abort an exchange cleanly; void a riposte; regain space from stretto to re-establish largo.
records.fullApplication: After your cut is parried, tornare immediately to void their riposte; present point-on as you retreat to discourage pursuit, then re-enter with an accrescere and thrust.

records.briefDefinition: The approach into fighting distance where the first credible threats are launched to seize initiative.
records.detailedDescription: The phase of closing from out of measure into range under cover of guards, feints, or point-on threats. The goal is to enter safely while forcing reactions.
records.application: Advance with point controlling the center (Longa/Fenestra); enter on an angle with a prepared strike or thrust to take the Vor.
records.fullApplication: Approach with a slight accrescere and point-on; when they parry or reach, step offline and strike in mezzo tempo; if they wait, pass with a fendente to bind on your forte.

records.briefDefinition: State of acting first and dictating tempo so the opponent must respond.
records.detailedDescription: You control timing by launching actions that force parries or binds, then immediately following before the opponent can take their own turn.
records.application: Strike decisively from pulsativa guards (Donna, Tutta Porta) or threaten point-on from Longa to keep the opponent reacting.
records.fullApplication: Open with a sharp fendente from Falcone; as they parry, turn the hands to a thrust without ceding tempo; if they remain passive, redouble mezzano to the hands to preserve Vor.

records.briefDefinition: Tactile reading of pressure in the blade bind—if they are hard, go soft; if soft, go strong.
records.detailedDescription: Use pressure and contact to decide whether to yield and wind around, or press through with cuts/thrusts. Core to actions at mezza spada.
records.application: At the bind, test: if you meet stiff resistance, slip or wind to the open line; if you feel weakness, thrust or cut through immediately.
records.fullApplication: Cross at mid-blade; feel them push hard—yield a little, slide off, and thrust around their blade; next exchange they’re soft—drive straight in on the line with point or fendente.

records.briefDefinition: Immediate continuation after a parried or missed attack without withdrawing or pausing.
records.detailedDescription: Replace the point or rebound the blade to a new opening before the opponent can riposte; favors compact hand turns and short lines.
records.application: After a thrust is beaten slightly off-line, replace the point instantly; after a cut is parried, let it rebound into a second cut or thrust.
records.fullApplication: Thrust from Longa; they beat weakly—keep forward intent and slide the point back onto center for a fast second thrust; or mandritto is parried—remise into riverso to the far opening.

records.briefDefinition: Fiore’s label for guards designed to deliver very powerful blows and break opposing guards.
records.detailedDescription: Positions like Posta di Donna and Tutta Porta di Ferro generate maximal force via body rotation and structure; used to seize momentum.
records.application: Adopt to open exchanges with committed fendenti or rising actions that overwhelm static defenses.
records.fullApplication: From Donna Destra, step diagonally and strike a hard fendente to break their cover; if checked, follow immediately with thrust or mezzano before they recover.

records.briefDefinition: Firm, rooted guards structured to receive force and riposte safely.
records.detailedDescription: Examples include Mezza Porta di Ferro and Dente di Cinghiaro; they close lines on the forte and resist displacement.
records.application: Wait in a stable guard to draw attacks, take them on the strong, and answer instantly.
records.fullApplication: In Mezza Porta di Ferro, meet the cut on your forte while stepping slightly offline, then thrust up the middle or drop a fendente as their blade rebounds.

records.briefDefinition: Mobile, deceptive guards used transiently to feint, probe, and transition—unsuited to absorbing heavy blows.
records.detailedDescription: Examples include Posta di Fenestra, Posta Longa, and Posta Breve; emphasize speed, deception, and quick conversion to cover or attack.
records.application: Use to invite and then change line: threaten point-on, void incoming cuts, and counter in mezzo tempo.
records.fullApplication: From Fenestra, show a high threat; as they cut, shift to catch or slip the blow and snap a straight thrust; from Longa, withdraw hands to void their beat and immediately strike.

records.briefDefinition: The beat or window in which an action occurs; acting in the correct moment decides exchanges.
records.detailedDescription: Includes initial time, mezzo tempo (striking during their motion), and counter-time. Economy of motion wins tempi and denies ripostes.
records.application: Interrupt wide preparations with a short thrust; riposte the instant a parry succeeds; avoid multi-tempo actions unless you control measure.
records.fullApplication: They raise to cut—turn the hands and deliver a straight punta in mezzo tempo; if you must parry, do so once and strike in the next beat before they can act.

records.briefDefinition: Management of distance: from out of measure to wide (largo) to close (stretto) and grappling range.
records.detailedDescription: Guards and footwork regulate entry and denial of measure. Wide play favors strikes with room to exit; close play favors binds, thrusts, and grapples.
records.application: Hold point-on to fix measure; accrescere to threaten safely; discressere/tornare to deny their reach; choose actions appropriate to distance.
records.fullApplication: Stand just outside reach in Breve to lure entry; as they step, extend to Longa and thrust before they arrive; if measure collapses to stretto, secure the weapon and finish with pommel or throw.
